titleStmt.title: Fertility outcome and information on fertility issues in individuals with different forms of disorders of sex development: findings from the dsd-LIFE study

analytic.title: Fertility outcome and information on fertility issues in individuals with different forms of disorders of sex development: findings from the dsd-LIFE study

biblStruct.note: Received May 31, 2017; revised August 4, 2017; accepted August 7, 2017;

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: Objective: To investigate fertility outcome in individuals with different forms of disorders of sex development (DSD), if assisted reproductive technology (ART) was used, and the patients' satisfaction with the information they had received.
Design: A cross-sectional multicenter study, dsd-LIFE.
Setting: Not applicable.
Patient(s): A total of 1,040 patients aged R16 years with different DSD diagnoses participated.
Intervention(s): A web-based questionnaire was filled out by all participants.
The participants could chose to take part in somatic investigations including ultrasonography.

Main Outcome Measure(s): Information on partner, number of children, ART, adoption and step-children, general health, presence of gonads and uterus, current education and economic situation, received information on fertility issues, and satisfaction with the information, was collected.
Result(s): In the total cohort, mean age 32 years, 33% lived with a partner, but only 14% reported having at least one child including 7% with ART, 4% adopted.
Only 3.5% of the total cohort had been able to reproduce without ART, most frequently women with congenital adrenal hyperplasia, and only 0.7% of participants with other diagnoses.
Of the participants, 72% had received information on fertility, but 17% were not satisfied with the information.
isorders of sex development (DSD) have been defined as congenital conditions in which the development of chromosomal, gonadal, or anatomical sex is atypical (1).
Such development often affects the ability to have biological children (2,3).
Fertility can be impaired because of biological reasons, such as gonadal and endocrine disturbances, or direct anatomical reasons inherent to the DSD.

The surgical and medical treatments that the patients with DSD undergo may also affect fertility, as well as psychological and psychosocial factors related to the conditions including age at diagnosis.
The possibility for fertility differs between the diagnostic groups.
Women with Turner syndrome are typically diagnosed due to short stature or lack of pubertal development as a result of ovarian failure.
However, some of these women may have spontaneous puberty and 5% of the cases become pregnant without health care intervention (4).

Men with Klinefelter syndrome are most often diagnosed in adolescence or adult life due to halted testicular development and T deficiency with delayed pubertal development and infertility because of azoospermia (5).
However, in about 8% of cases sperms were found in semen (6).

In complete gonadal dysgenesis (CGD), both 46,XX and 46,XY, there is no gonadal development, which means that external genitalia will be female and the M€ ullerian structures (i.e., uterus and vagina) develop due to lack of antim€ ullerian hormone (2).
The absence of pubertal development is most often what leads to diagnosis.
Pregnancy may be achieved by oocyte donation (7)(8)(9).

Partial gonadal dysgenesis (PGD) in individuals with 46,XX karyotype result in a phenotype similar to CGD, whereas PGD in individuals with the 46,XY karyotype may lead to varying degrees of external virilization and the presence of an uterus or uterus remnants (2,10).
In severe forms patients are infertile (azoospermia), but, for example, SF-1/NR5A1 mutations result in variable testicular function and viable sperm (11).
Similarly, mixed gonadal dysgenesis (MGD) (i.e., 45,X/46,XY karyotype) may result in genital development varying from female to male with or without uterus (12)(13)(14).
Germ cells are not present in most cases, yet in some cases testicular sperm extraction may be possible (14).
Ovotesticular DSD (OT) is defined as the situation when both ovarian and testicular tissue is present irrespective of karyotype.
The development of the external genitalia and internal structures is dependent on the hormonal function of the testicular part of the gonad(s) (15,16).
The ovarian function is often better preserved than the testicular portion.
Preservation of ovarian tissue in patients reared as females may enable preserved fertility with their own oocytes (3,17,18).

Individuals with 46,XY karyotype and complete androgen insensitivity (CAIS) have testes with T and anti-m€ ullerian hormone production, resulting in female phenotype, but absence of both M€ ullerian and Wolffian structures (i.e., uterus and proximal part of the vagina).
The seminiferous tubules are unable to produce spermatozoa (3,19,20).
Partial androgen insensitivity (PAIS) results in a more varied phenotype depending on the residual androgen receptor function with external genitalia varying from ambiguous to virtually male.
The testes may be descended or not and the development of the Wolffian ducts may be normal or defective (3,19,21).
The spermatogenesis has been reported to range from azoospermia to complete spermatogenesis (20,22,23).
In XX males with SRY translocation, genital development results in male phenotype with small testes and azoospermia (24).

Androgen synthesis defects, such as 17b-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase type 3 and 5a-reductase type 2 deficiency, result in varying degrees of under-masculinization depending on the enzyme deficiency (25).
Individuals with these deficiencies have often been brought up as girls, but if testes are retained they virilize during puberty due to activation of isoenzymes (26,27).
Affected individuals may be infertile due to the lack of spermatogenesis; however, fertility is likely in those with milder phenotype (28).
Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) is caused by enzyme deficiencies in the steroid hormone synthesis in the adrenals and results in varying degrees of cortisol deficiency.
Most common is 21-hydroxylase deficiency, which results in increased androgen production in utero and is the most common cause of ambiguous genital development in 46,XX individuals (29).
Reduced fertility for women and men has been reported for all forms of CAH (30)(31)(32)(33)(34).
With the development of modern medical technologies and treatment opportunities views on DSD treatment have changed and fertility diagnostics, information, and treatment take a new meaning.
Assisted reproductive technology (ART) has developed during the past decades.

More recent techniques, such as intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) and testicular sperm retrieval, have further improved the possibilities for these patients to become biological parents (35,36).
There is an opportunity to give birth to a non-biological child by embryo donation with the presence of a uterus (18,37).
The ART has an improving success rate and has become more available.

Yet there are differences in availability in countries across Europe, which may depend on the individuals' economic situation and education, but also ethical issues and legislation in the different countries.
Although fertility issues among individuals with atypical sex development seem to be of vital importance, this has not been fully investigated.
The knowledge among affected individuals on how the disorders influence fertility is to a large degree dependent on the information given by the health care providers.
Psychological aspects, including sexuality, sexual orientation, and psychosocial reasons, may also affect the possibility of having one's own children.
In addition, the wish to have children is not of high priority for everyone.
The importance of having one's own biological children differs between individuals and is very personal.

This study was undertaken as part of dsd-LIFE, a comprehensive study investigating medical, surgical, psychological, and ethical issues and patients' own views on these issues aiming to improve treatment and care of patients with different diagnoses of DSD.

The aim of this descriptive study was to investigate to what extent patients with different forms of DSD live in relationships and have children (biological, adopted, or stepchildren), and whether ART had been available and used by the patients.
Furthermore, we enquired whether the patients had received information about their fertility and if they were satisfied with how fertility issues were explained and discussed by the clinicians.
The dsd-LIFE is a cross-sectional multicenter clinical evaluation study.
Patients with a diagnosis defined under the umbrella term DSD were included.
The study was funded by the European Union, Seventh Framework Program (FP7/2007-2013) (www.dsd-life.eu).
Details of the study design have been described elsewhere (38).
Patients R16 years were recruited in 6 European countries (Germany, France, the Netherlands, Poland, Sweden, and United Kingdom) at 14 A web-based questionnaire was filled out by all participants.
The participants could chose whether they also wanted to take part in somatic investigations including ultrasonography, semen analysis, and bone mineral density.
Here we are focusing on questions on fertility and on living conditions such as gender, partner, and children (own biological, adopted, and stepchildren).
The question whether ART was used was specified as IVF, sperm or egg donation.

Patients who stated that they were unable to have biological children were asked about their desire to have fertility treatment in the past or in the future, if there had been or will be such a possibility.
Examples of specific questions on the information received were: Was the question of fertility discussed with you by your doctor?
Were you informed about possible infertility treatments?
Are you satisfied with the way the question of fertility was discussed?
Answers to questions on income, education, and general health status were also studied.
The presence of gonads and uterus was established on the basis of ultrasonography.
Information about gonadectomy was retrieved from medical charts and patient-reported data (39).
Continuous parameters are shown as mean AE SD, whereas categorical data are presented as absolute and relative frequencies.
For statistical analysis of group differences the Fisher's exact test for count data was used.
The Pearson's c 2 test was applied, if the Fisher's exact test was technically not possible.
If group differences were present (P< .05),
post-hoc analysis using c 2 tests was performed.
General characteristics of different diagnostic groups are presented in Table 1.
Female gender was reported in 717, male gender in 310, and other or neither gender in 12 participants.
Mean age was 32.4 AE 13.6 years (range, 16-75 years).
The youngest were male patients with PAIS (23.6 AE 5.6 years) and among the oldest were patients with Klinefelter syndrome (39.6 AE 15.1 years) and XX males (41.2 AE 11.2 years).
Most of the participants reported medium or high education (69%) and a low educational level was reported by 19%.

The lowest education (low or medium) was reported by patients with androgen biosynthesis defects (69% women and 100% men) and Klinefelter syndrome (75% men), as well as the males with PAIS (88%); however, they had the lowest mean age and some might still be in education.
Most study participants reported living comfortably or were coping with the present income versus 12% of persons who stated that they had difficulties.
The general health was self-assessed as good or fair by most of the patients in all groups (Table 1).
The information from ultrasonography of the gonads revealed that in 20% of the examined patients gonads were not found.
Information about surgery from medical notes and the patients' own reports revealed that unilateral or bilateral gonadectomy was performed in 46% of women and 35% of men.
Uterus was present in all women with Turner syndrome and >95% of women with CGD, PGD, OT, MGD, and CAH for whom the ultrasonography was performed.
However, ultrasonography was performed in only 27% of the patients.
A total of 381 individuals had a partner (33%) (Table 1)-24% reported being single and 31% lived with their parents.
Women and men in the different diagnostic groups had a partner in a similar proportion (average, 35% and 33%, respectively), and most in the group of 12 individuals with other gender (average, 62%).
The total number of individuals who had at least one child with or without ART (IVF, egg or sperm donation) or adopted was 144 (14%), in addition 44 had stepchildren (Table 2).
In the total cohort 35 (3.5%) had reproduced without ART-32 women and 3 men.
However, two of these had additional children also through ART (one person with CAH and one with Klinefelter syndrome).
Women with CAH had conceived naturally in 28 cases (15% of all women with 46,XX CAH).

Patients with other diagnoses than CAH had children without ART in %7 cases: two patients with Klinefelter syndrome (1% of all with Klinefelter syndrome), four with Turner syndrome (1.4% of all with Turner syndrome), and only one of the patients with idiopathic hypospadias (i.e., without molecular diagnosis).
However, the mean age in the hypospadias group was only 24 years.
In the total cohort the number of children per individual with at least one child ranged from 1-5.
In 71 cases children were conceived through some form of ART-7% of the total cohort and almost half of the individuals with at least one child.
All the individuals who had received ART were R29 years.
Sperm donation was most common (40 cases: 38 Klinefelter, 1 PGD, and 1 XX male).
Egg donation had been performed in 16 women with Turner syndrome, 2 with MGD, 1 with CGD, and 1 with CAH.

Patients who had children with ART were most frequently men, with higher or medium education, living comfortably or coping with the present income, with very good or good health, having received information on fertility issues, and were satisfied with the discussion about fertility with their care provider (Fig. 1).
In 38 cases (4% of the total cohort) a child was adopted.
Because 144 individuals had at least one child, this means that 26% of those having a child had children through adoption.
Among the women, 24 (3%), and the men, 12 (4%), and the individuals identifying as other/neither sex, only 1, had adopted a child.
Adoption was more common among the older patients (R29 years), which may not be surprising.
There were 44 (5% of the total cohort) stepchildren reported, spread among 13 of the diagnoses.
As could be expected, it was more common to have the stepchildren among participants who had a partner.
The participants who lived with their parents had significantly less often children (P< .001).

Although differences in income or perceived health did not affect having children, participants with higher educational level had a child in 26.5% compared with 18% among those with medium or low education (P< .01).

On the question whether they remembered having received information about fertility issues from their doctor or health care professional, 72% of the patients in the total cohort (75% women, 63% men) responded that they had received such information (Table 3).
The received information differed between the diagnostic groups.
The response also differed for men and women with the same diagnosis, as was the case for the group with PGD, OT, MGD (80% women and 49% men), and PAIS (75% women and 40% men).
However, the total number of patients in these groups was small.

Among the patients who remembered receiving such information, 53% were satisfied with the way the question of fertility was discussed (56% women, 41% men, and none from those with other gender) (Table 3).

In the total cohort, 30% were neither satisfied nor dissatisfied with the information, and about 17% were not satisfied with the way the question of fertility was discussed (14% women, 21% men, and 75% other).

div.head: Knowledge about the Possibility of Having Biological Children

p.s: Regarding the possibility of having their own biological children, 20% responded that they do not know whether they can, 62% that they cannot, and 18% that they can have their own biological children (Table 3).

Slightly more women than men said they knew they cannot have biological children (67% vs. 60%, respectively), but the men more often did not know whether this was the case (28% compared with 17% of the women).
This is in line with the result that the women more often had received information about fertility.
There were differences between the diagnostic groups for this question.
Women with Turner syndrome reported that they knew they could not have their own biological children in 77% and men with Klinefelter in 79%.

Women with PGD, OT, or MGD said they did not know in 9%, could not in 87%, and could have children in 4% and men in the same group more often did not know (36%), whereas 54% reported that they could not and 7% reported being able to have their own biological children.

Women with CAIS mostly (99%) responded that they knew they could not have biological children, whereas there was a difference for patients with PAIS, with 100% of the women and 20% of the men responding that they could not have biological children.
Those individuals who answered that they were unable to have biological children were asked about their desire to have fertility treatment in the past or in the future.
The responses varied between 33% and 67% (average, 55%) among diagnostic groups.
About 40% indicated that they would like to try new fertility treatment techniques in the future (Table 3).
This study is the first to report on fertility outcome in the whole spectrum of DSD diagnoses in a large European follow-up.
In this dsd-LIFE cohort the fertility outcome in individuals with different forms of DSD was greatly affected.
Only 14% of the participants reported having at least one child, and half of those had conceived with ART (i.e., IVF, sperm or egg donation).
Individuals with diagnoses other than CAH conceived without ART in <1%.
It was expected that individuals with DSD have few children as disorders of gonadal development affect the gamete production and in many cases the development of internal and external genitalia.
In addition, in many individuals gonadectomy had been performed due to the risk of future malignancies or to prevent unwanted hormone production.

Although the general health and economic situation of the patients did not seem to be an important cause for the low number of children, only about one-third of the participants reported having a partner.
This could be an important factor affecting the number of children in this cohort.
About one-fourth of the individuals with a child had adopted.
It was most common among the women with CAIS and Turner syndrome, as well as the men with Klinefelter syndrome.
One can speculate that earlier information about fertility/infertility may be of importance for adoption, as well as the frequency of having partners in the different diagnostic groups.
The cost for adoption is considerable and rules for adoption may also make it more difficult for individuals and couples with DSD.
About 60% of the patients reported that they knew that they could not have their own biological children.

It was more common among the women to respond that they had received fertility information, possibly because information about not having a uterus is easily understood, and is most often conveyed to the patient.
Many patients in this study cohort had had the gonads removed, which reflects the medical treatment policy that has prevailed during several decades.
The decisions were made considering the future risk of malignancies in the gonads, but also when gender assignment decisions made the gonadal hormone production unwanted.
Information given under such circumstances would also be expected to make it clear to the patient that this results in infertility.
Assisted reproductive technology was more common among the older participants-the youngest person receiving ART was 29 years old.
This could be due to the cost of receiving that kind of treatment, but also the educational level or the effect of age per se.
The chance of having a partner and the wish to have children and form a family may increase with age.
About 7% of the patients had children through ART (IVF, sperm or egg donation), but we do not know how many had tried to conceive without succeeding in having a child.
However, of those who responded to the question about desiring fertility treatment, if possible (in the past or in the future), only about half responded that they were interested.
It can be interpreted to mean that others were not interested in spending time and effort into having children (39).
However, the relatively low mean age in some of the diagnostic groups should be considered.
In the European Union countries the mean age for having the first child is 29 years for women and 31 years for men (40,41).
The proportion of women who have at least one child at age 30 years is about 50% and the proportion of men about 40%.

Hence, firm conclusions on fertility or number of children in a lifetime perspective cannot be drawn from this study, although it is highly unlikely that the number of children will increase to such an extent that it will become close to the general population.
In addition to a ''regular'' IVF treatment there are many interventions that may improve the fertility possibilities and that need to be individualized.
In the near future more possibilities may open with improved hormonal treatment and other technologies.
A hypoplastic uterus can be stimulated using estrogen (E)/progestagen therapy to accommodate a pregnancy and facilitate tubal procedures in patients with normal fallopian tubes (42).
Experimental treatment with uterus transplantation has started in Sweden (43), and a few children have been born this way.

In addition, microsurgical testicular sperm extraction (TESE) combined with ICSI represents promising chances for some azoospermic men with Klinefelter syndrome, testicular dysgenesis, and PAIS to father children (14,44,45).
The availability of ART differs greatly in countries, also within Europe and the European Union (46).
It is not uncommon that the individual has to pay the full cost for the treatment, if it is available at all.
For example, in Poland, the first IVF was performed in 1987 and since then IVF, sperm, egg, and embryo donations, have been available mostly in private clinics.
In Germany, half of the costs for IVF or ICSI are usually paid by the patients, the other half by the health insurance.
Countries, like Sweden, the Netherlands, the United Kingdom, and France with complete coverage of treatments through national health plans have the highest level of ART utilization.
However, the long wait demands that some patients use private clinics with high prices.
Egg donation is a technique that is not practiced in all countries, for instance, in France and Germany it is prohibited.
Adoption is a solution for many couples, but procedures may be complicated by rules about economic situation, heterosexual marriage, and other prerequisites stated by the child's country of origin.
In addition it may be costly for the parents.
In the past, gonadectomy was often performed in individuals with DSD already in early childhood, because of the potential risk of malignancy in the dysplastic gonad.

Especially, the high risk of germ cell tumors occurring after puberty in the dysgenetic gonads of patients with Y chromosome and their poor hormonal and gametogenic function were the reasons for the recommendation of gonadectomy before puberty (47)(48)(49).
However, prophylactic gonadectomy may deprive some patients with DSD their chance for fertility (50).
In addition, female sex of rearing was more often chosen in patients with ambiguous genitalia in the past (51).
The approach to the issue is now changing with increasing efforts to individualize treatment.
The necessity to remove gonads in patients with DSD should be assessed individually, based on gonadal cancer risk.
Biopsy of gonads in gonadal dysgenesis and androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS) should be performed before or during puberty to identify neoplastic lesions (52,53).
In the present study, more patients with DSD (about one-third) did not remember receiving information on their fertility.
In addition there was little satisfaction with the information that was received in 17% of the whole cohort.
These results emphasize the need to improve and individualize the care with special focus on information about fertility and possibilities for becoming a parent.
This is especially important as the diagnostic and treatment possibilities are improving.
Full disclosure about the disorder and its effect on the patients' lives is now considered one of the important aspects and a cornerstone in health care.
However, this has not always been the case.
The issue of fertility is sometimes not brought up until adolescence or even later.
In addition, the patient may not be interested in discussing such matters as a child, and therefore not remember or understand as much of the information given.
In childhood, the information may have been given to the parents at an early stage and then not brought up again until much later or not at all.
Information about fertility and about fertility treatment may not have been considered appropriate until the patient reaches adulthood, or adult care.
However, information can be given in many ways and during various stages of development.
Health care providers need to develop methods of discussing these complicated matters in a sensitive but comprehensible way.
It is essential that patients make conscious decisions about their lives, while fully informed about their bodies and the available medical treatments and interventions.
This study shows that the information on fertility problems and treatment possibilities given to patients with DSD needs to be improved.

It should be given in an age appropriate way, several times from childhood through adolescence and in adulthood until the patient is fully informed about all relevant aspects of the treatment and treatment options.
The satisfaction with how fertility problems have been discussed in the past shows that there is much room for improvement.
The information available about fertility possibilities, the possible ways to solve the different problems, and the types of fertility treatment that can be offered to patients with DSD is complex.
Therefore, close collaboration in multidisciplinary teams familiar with the specific reproduction issues of individuals with DSD is essential to improve the situation.
In conclusion, in our study fertility was, as expected, significantly reduced in all types of DSD and the situation differed considerably between the diagnostic groups.
Hence, treatment needs to be individualized.
Fertility potential should be assessed individually during adolescence and in adulthood based on gonadal presence, hormonal function, sperm/oocyte production, and anatomical possibilities.
Our study showed that not all patients with DSD are optimally informed about their fertility potential.
Yet, all patients with DSD have the right to be fully informed on their fertility status and possibilities of fertility treatment.
In providing this information age and educational background need to be considered.
The care should be individualized and the new possibilities of medicine should be incorporated.
To achieve this a multidisciplinary team approach is necessary.

Acknowledgment: The authors are grateful to all participants in the dsd-LIFE study and to all of the study centers for their dedication to contact potential participants and collecting high-quality data.
We especially want to thank the support groups in the different countries.
An overview of all contributors is given in the study protocol by Roehle et al. (38).
